question_paper.question_paper_name: IIT M FOUNDATION DIPLOMA ENDTERM QPD2 07 Aug 2022 IBA

questions.question_text_1: Read the following passage and answer the given subquestions that follow:  It was in the times of Wajid Ali Shah. Lucknow was drowned in sensuality. The big and small, the rich and the poor – all were sunk in it. Some were engrossed in dance and music; some just revelled in the drowsiness induced by opium. Love of pleasure dominated every aspect of life. In administration, in literature, in social life, in arts and crafts, in business and industry, in cuisine and custom – sensuality ruled everywhere. The state officials were absorbed in fun and pleasure, poets in descriptions of love and separation, artisans in zari and chikan work, businessmen in dealings in surma, perfumes and cosmetics. All were drowned in sensual pleasures. No one knew what was happening around the world. Quail fights were on. Rings were being readied for partridge fights. Somewhere the game of chausar was being played, with its attendant shouts on the winning throw. Elsewhere a pitched chessboard battle was on. From the king to the pauper – all were engrossed in these pleasures. So much so, that if beggars received money in alms, they preferred to spend it on opium or its extract rather than bread. ‘Playing games like chess or cards or ganjifa sharpens the mind, improves mental faculties and helps in solving complex problems.’ Such arguments were being forcefully advanced. (People subscribing to this thesis can be found even today.) So if Mirza Sajjad Ali and Mir Roshan Ali spent most of their time sharpening their wits, how could any thoughtful person take exception. Both of them were hereditary Jagirdars, free from the worries of a livelihood; they enjoyed their good food without having to work at all. What else could they do? ~  Chess Players - Premchand

So much so, that if beggars received money in alms, they preferred to spend it on opium or its extract rather than bread. ‘Playing games like chess or cards or ganjifa sharpens the mind, improves mental faculties and helps in solving complex problems.’ Such arguments were being forcefully advanced. (People subscribing to this thesis can be found even today.) So if Mirza Sajjad Ali and Mir Roshan Ali spent most of their time sharpening their wits, how could any thoughtful person take exception. Both of them were hereditary Jagirdars, free from the worries of a livelihood; they enjoyed their good food without having to work at all. What else could they do? ~  Chess Players - Premchand

questions.question_text_1: What can be identified during the reign of Wajid Ali Shah?
question_texts: What can be identified during the reign of Wajid Ali Shah?

options.option_text: Lucknow was facing the threat of invasion.
People were dissatisfied under the rule of Wajid Ali Shah.

parent_question.question_text_1: Read the following passage and answer the given subquestions that follow:  It was in the times of Wajid Ali Shah. Lucknow was drowned in sensuality. The big and small, the rich and the poor – all were sunk in it. Some were engrossed in dance and music; some just revelled in the drowsiness induced by opium. Love of pleasure dominated every aspect of life. In administration, in literature, in social life, in arts and crafts, in business and industry, in cuisine and custom – sensuality ruled everywhere. The state officials were absorbed in fun and pleasure, poets in descriptions of love and separation, artisans in zari and chikan work, businessmen in dealings in surma, perfumes and cosmetics. All were drowned in sensual pleasures. No one knew what was happening around the world. Quail fights were on. Rings were being readied for partridge fights. Somewhere the game of chausar was being played, with its attendant shouts on the winning throw. Elsewhere a pitched chessboard battle was on. From the king to the pauper – all were engrossed in these pleasures. So much so, that if beggars received money in alms, they preferred to spend it on opium or its extract rather than bread. ‘Playing games like chess or cards or ganjifa sharpens the mind, improves mental faculties and helps in solving complex problems.’ Such arguments were being forcefully advanced. (People subscribing to this thesis can be found even today.) So if Mirza Sajjad Ali and Mir Roshan Ali spent most of their time sharpening their wits, how could any thoughtful person take exception. Both of them were hereditary Jagirdars, free from the worries of a livelihood; they enjoyed their good food without having to work at all. What else could they do? ~  Chess Players - Premchand

The state officials were absorbed in fun and pleasure, poets in descriptions of love and separation, artisans in zari and chikan work, businessmen in dealings in surma, perfumes and cosmetics. All were drowned in sensual pleasures. No one knew what was happening around the world. Quail fights were on. Rings were being readied for partridge fights. Somewhere the game of chausar was being played, with its attendant shouts on the winning throw. Elsewhere a pitched chessboard battle was on. From the king to the pauper – all were engrossed in these pleasures. So much so, that if beggars received money in alms, they preferred to spend it on opium or its extract rather than bread. ‘Playing games like chess or cards or ganjifa sharpens the mind, improves mental faculties and helps in solving complex problems.’ Such arguments were being forcefully advanced. (People subscribing to this thesis can be found even today.) So if Mirza Sajjad Ali and Mir Roshan Ali spent most of their time sharpening their wits, how could any thoughtful person take exception. Both of them were hereditary Jagirdars, free from the worries of a livelihood; they enjoyed their good food without having to work at all. What else could they do? ~  Chess Players - Premchand

questions.question_text_1: The poets in Lucknow were ____________.
question_texts: The poets in Lucknow were ____________.

options.option_text: Writing poems of love and separation

It flew away as I approached. 5)______ shadows stared.  Based on the above data, answer the given subquestions.
question_texts: Fill in the blanks with the right options.  1) _____, the house had appeared enormous. 2)____, beside the new grey buildings towering above it like unfriendly giants, it seemed a miserable shack. The old Naga tree 3) _______ its dry branches towards eternity, covering the roof with sickly yellow leaves. A funereal crow 4) _______ croaking on a wire. It flew away as I approached. 5)______ shadows stared.  Based on the above data, answer the given subquestions.

question_texts: “I can’t believe Raksha told the management about Rashi’s plans of eventually quitting the company – I didn’t think she was someone who would ________________________.”

questions.question_text_1: Consider the following sentences:  (1) I sleep. (2) I work out every day. (3) I love mangoes.  Which of the above sentences has an explicit object?
question_texts: Consider the following sentences:  (1) I sleep. (2) I work out every day. (3) I love mangoes.  Which of the above sentences has an explicit object?

options.option_text: Had been left in the rain

questions.question_text_1: What does “apple of one’s eye” mean?
question_texts: What does “apple of one’s eye” mean?

options.option_text: A thing or person which someone loves above all others
A memory of something that makes one nostalgic

props.summary:
Below is a structured summary of the core topics, concepts, and principles essential for the **"Foundation Level: Semester 1: English 1"** exam, based on the provided question paper.
The exam covers **4 broad areas**:
1. **Reading Comprehension** (Literary and Informative Passages)
2. **Grammar and Syntax** (Parts of Speech, Sentence Structure, Tenses, Subject-Verb Agreement)
3. **Vocabulary and Word Usage** (Synonyms, Collocations, Word Stress, Syllables)
4. **Listening and Speaking Skills** (Telephonic Conversations, Pauses, Pronunciation)

---

---

### **1. Reading Comprehension**
#### **Core Topics:**
- **Literary Passages** (e.g., *Chess Players* by Premchand)
  - Themes: Decadence, sensuality, societal decline, historical context (e.g., Wajid Ali Shah’s reign).
  - Key Ideas:
    - Lucknow’s cultural and moral decay during Wajid Ali Shah’s rule.
    - Addiction to opium, leisure (chess, quail/partridge fights), and neglect of governance.
    - Satirical portrayal of hereditary jagirdars (e.g., Mirza Sajjad Ali, Mir Roshan Ali).
  - **Vocabulary in Context**:
    - *Sensuality* → Erotic (Q3)
    - *Revel* → Celebrate (Q6)
    - *Engross* → Engage (Q10)
    - *Thesis* → Central argument (e.g., "games sharpen the mind") (Q5).

- **Informative Passages** (e.g., Audio on Neptune’s moon **Triton**)
  - Key Facts:
    - Triton’s orbit is **retrograde** (against Neptune’s rotation) (Q16).
    - Possible futures: Crash into Neptune or form a ring system (Q20).
    - Past theories: Former dwarf planet or part of a double system (Q19).
    - Geological activity: One of four known active objects in the solar system (Q14).
  - **Comparisons**:
    - Surface area > Australia but < Russia (Q15).
    - 14 moons; Triton is the largest (Q12, Q13).

#### **Key Skills:**
- Identifying **main ideas**, **supporting details**, and **inferences**.
- **True/False** statements based on textual evidence (Q7, Q8).
- **Vocabulary substitution** (Q3, Q6, Q10).

---

### **2. Grammar and Syntax**
#### **Core Topics:**
- **Subject-Verb Agreement**:
  - Singular/plural rules (Q46: *Birds **fly***; Q48: *Apple **has launched***).
  - Collective nouns (Q53: *They **cook** dinner together* → Correct).
- **Tenses**:
  - Present simple (habits: *I work out every day*) (Q51).
  - Present perfect (*has launched*) vs. simple past (*launched*).
- **Parts of Speech**:
  - **Adjectives**: Qualify nouns (Q59: *insightful* modifies *questions*).
  - **Nouns as Subjects**: (Q60: *The bicycle* is the subject).
- **Sentence Structure**:
  - **Commands vs. Requests** (Q49: Teacher’s statement is a **command**).
  - **Explicit Objects**: Transitive verbs require objects (Q51: *I love **mangoes***).
  - **Error Spotting**: (Q47: *Payasam is a **delicacy*** → Correct form; "delicacies" is plural).

#### **Key Rules:**
| Concept               | Example                                  | Rule                                                                 |
|-----------------------|------------------------------------------|----------------------------------------------------------------------|
| **Subject-Verb Agreement** | Birds **fly**.                           | Plural subjects take plural verbs.                                  |
| **Present Simple**    | She **goes** to college.                  | 3rd person singular adds *-s*.                                      |
| **Transitive Verbs**  | I love **mangoes**.                      | Requires a direct object.                                            |
| **Comparatives**      | Jane is **taller** than Anne.             | *-er* for short adjectives; *more* for long ones.                   |
| **Stress Patterns**   | *Biological* → bio**log**ical            | Stress shifts with suffixes (e.g., *-ical*, *-ate*).                |

---

### **3. Vocabulary and Word Usage**
#### **Core Topics:**
- **Synonyms/Antonyms**:
  - *Sensuality* = Erotic (Q3); *Revel* = Celebrate (Q6).
  - *Catapult* ≠ Screech (Q17); *Ground* = Crushed (Q18).
- **Collocations** (Q32–Q36):
  | Word      | Collocation       |
  |-----------|-------------------|
  | Added     | **Advantage**     |
  | Sound     | **Advice**        |
  | Tacit     | **Agreement**     |
  | Endless   | **Fight**         |
  | Built-up  | **Area**          |
- **Word Stress** (Q44, Q54–Q57):
  - *Project* (verb: *pro**ject*; noun: **pro**ject).
  - *Biological* → bio**log**ical (stress on 3rd syllable).
  - *Procedure* → pro**ce**dure (2nd syllable).
- **Syllables** (Q22–Q24, Q42–Q43):
  - *Destiny* = 3; *Successful* = 3; *Environment* = 4.
  - *Erode* = Disyllabic; *Revenue* = 3 syllables.

#### **Key Patterns:**
- **Aspirated Stops**: /t/, /p/, /k/ with a puff of air (Q45: *Test*, *Imply*).
- **Idioms**:
  - *Apple of one’s eye* = Cherished person (Q61).
  - *Sell someone out* = Betray (Q50).

---

### **4. Listening and Speaking Skills**
#### **Core Topics:**
- **Telephonic Conversations** (Q27–Q31):
  - **Phrases**:
    - *How may I help you?* (Q27).
    - *Your voice is breaking* (Q28).
    - *Are you there?* (Q29).
    - *Hanging up* = Ending a call (Q30, Q31).
- **Pauses in Speech** (Q25–Q26):
  - Natural pauses at **clause boundaries**:
    - *If you think you cannot make a difference/ I would say you very well can//*
- **Pronunciation**:
  - **Syllable Stress**: Affects meaning (e.g., *PROject* vs. *proJECT*).
  - **Aspiration**: /t/ in *stem* (unvoiced) vs. *test* (aspirated).

---

### **Mermaid Knowledge Graphs**
#### **1. Reading Comprehension Topics**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Reading Comprehension] --> B[Literary Passages]
    A --> C[Informative Passages]
    B --> D[Themes: Decadence, Sensuality]
    B --> E[Vocabulary: Sensuality=Erotic, Revel=Celebrate]
    B --> F[Historical Context: Wajid Ali Shah]
    C --> G[Triton: Neptune's Moon]
    C --> H[Key Facts: Orbit, Surface Area, Geology]
    C --> I[Comparisons: Moons, Planets]
```

#### **2. Grammar and Syntax Topics**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Grammar] --> B[Subject-Verb Agreement]
    A --> C[Tenses]
    A --> D[Parts of Speech]
    A --> E[Sentence Structure]
    B --> F[Singular/Plural Rules]
    C --> G[Present Simple vs. Perfect]
    D --> H[Adjectives, Nouns, Verbs]
    E --> I[Commands vs. Requests]
    E --> J[Explicit Objects]
```

#### **3. Vocabulary and Collocations**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Vocabulary] --> B[Synonyms/Antonyms]
    A --> C[Collocations]
    A --> D[Word Stress]
    A --> E[Syllables]
    B --> F[Sensuality=Erotic, Ground=Crushed]
    C --> G[Added Advantage, Sound Advice]
    D --> H[Biological: bio-log-i-cal]
    E --> I[Destiny=3, Environment=4]
```

#### **4. Listening/Speaking Skills**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Listening/Speaking] --> B[Telephonic Phrases]
    A --> C[Pauses in Speech]
    A --> D[Pronunciation]
    B --> E[How may I help you?, Hanging up]
    C --> F[Clause Boundaries: If you think.../ I would say...//]
    D --> G[Stress: PROject vs. proJECT]
    D --> H[Aspiration: Test, Imply]
```

---
### **Key Equations (N/A for English)**
Since this is an **English** exam, there are no mathematical equations. However, **patterns** like syllable counting or stress rules can be represented as:
- **Syllable Rule**: `Word = (Vowel Sounds) → Count`.
  Example: *Environment* = *En-vi-ron-ment* → **4 syllables**.
- **Stress Rule**: `Stress shifts with suffixes`.
  Example: *Photograph* (1st syllable) → *Photographic* (3rd syllable).
